Award.AwardTitle: The Science of the Narwhal through Technological Innovation, HoloLens
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the synergy between new scientific technology and new scientific information on the narwhal to the public through a transformational technology, HoloLens. Microsoft's HoloLens has transformed academic and professional platforms of learning. The holographic computer headset brings holographic wonders into the viewers own world superimposing virtual objects over the wearer's field of vision. As opposed to virtual reality that isolates and transports the viewer into a different world, multiple wearers of HoloLens can participate in the same holographic experience. Case Western Reserve University Interactive Commons was selected by Microsoft as the experimental ground for the academic implementation of HoloAnatomy, teaching anatomy through life-like holograms.

HoloLens technology will bring narwhal anatomy, ecology and behavior to Museum visitors by exploring holographic narwhal images as told by a holographic Inuit narrator. The innovative technology will transform the museum experience as multiple participants can enter a traditional background exhibit of fixed objects while holographic narwhals are swimming in the same room. Through 3D holographic animations, museum visitors will be actively engaged in the Inuit hunter presentation and be able to experience and understand and even walk around the 3D Holographic narwhal and hunter animations. As one example, Inuit observed differences in body and tusk form will help direct the body of scientific knowledge and direct transformative scientific discoveries of the tusk. Outreach through collaborative museum narwhal exhibits and educational programs will be implemented.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaboration on the Narwhal HoloLens Experience has been completed between narrator and lead narwhal researcher, Dr. Martin Nweeia, assistant professor at Case Western Reserve School of Dental Medicine, graphic and 3D artist Kevin Hand, artists from Michigan State University, 3D Animation and Media Department, and the Interactive Commons at Case Western Reserve University to create an educational museum exhibit and school program based on cutting edge science and Inuit knowledge about the narwhal. The experience features this unique Arctic megafauna as visualized through Microsoft Hololens, an innovative, new, augmented-reality headset.

Hololens is a new technology from Microsoft that  transforms methods and approaches to learning. It is a holographic computer built into a headset that allows a full experience of sound, sight, and exploration of holograms within a space, superimposing virtual objects over one's field of vision. Unlike the isolation of virtual reality that transports the wearer in to a different world, Hololens brings holographic wonders into the viewer's world. When one wears Hololens, they are aware of the room they are in as well as others in the room.  If others are also wearing Hololens, they can all interact on the same holographic image all while seeing each other and their surroundings. The recent application to education platforms was given to Case School of Medicine under principal investigator Dr. Mark Griswold  to teach human anatomy in the medical school, and the Interactive Commons at Case is helping to facilitate this transformation in medical education. Other disciplines also are utilizing this technology in myriad fields of architecture, design, art and science. The Interactive Commons brings together diverse expertise to solve complex problems, supported by visualization. In this institute, dedicated teams of computer programmers, 3D modelers, artists and curriculum designers work together to develop applications for Microsoft HoloLens and other visualization technologies. 

Recent scientific discoveries and collected Inuit oral knowledge published by Dr Martin Nweeia are rendered through this proprietary technology that tells a new story about the narwhal. Inuit knowledge that has transformed the method of scientific inquiry in this research is shared and narrated with the help of an artistically derived 3D Inuk with animations created by the artistic team. The experience will provide a platform for multiple Hololens users to participate in the same interactive holographic experience together. The story of the narwhal and its extraordinary tooth will be told through the narration of Martin Nweeia, lead scientist for Narwhal Tusk Research and assistant professor at the Case School of Dental Medicine. Hololens participants will learn about the knowledge Inuit have contributed as full partners in recent scientific studies of migration, distribution, anatomy and behavior and the understanding of the narwhal?s tusk function.  This invaluable Inuit knowledge has contributed aspects of narwhal anatomy, morphology, distribution, migration and behavior to allow the scientific investigation to follow a pathway to better understand this enigmatic and elusive cetacean.

Dr. Nweeia will also assist participants through the experience as they discover this Arctic whale close up, and the discoveries made by integrating Inuit knowledge with scientific results. A narwhal family will approach the participants and the narrator will explain how to prepare and use the headset and then present some background on recent scientific discoveries. An Inuit elder will then walk toward the group and explain the traditional knowledge that has added to the body of science, including aspects of anatomy, tooth morphology, migration, distribution and behavior.  The partnership between Inuit and scientists will be highlighted, and their discoveries explained. The narrator will walk the visitor through a series of anatomic landmarks and physiology, focusing first on the tooth sensory organ system and second describing insights gathered from sequencing the narwhal genome both investigations led by Dr. Nweeia.  Future studies and the significance of genomic research will inform the visitor of the value of such work.  Finally, the participants will engage in an interactive holographic game, stunning oncoming fish as each of their heads becomes a holographic narwhal head with a tusk that has the ability to stun fish, a theory that has helps explain how narwhal forage for fish.  The game winner is celebrated at the end of the experience.
